MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Flight Modes lesson of the Lunar Module Academy.
In this lesson, we will focus on the Primary Guidance and Navigation System (PNGS). The Abort Guidance System (AGS) is a backup system to the PNGS, not yet implemented in Reentry.
The guidance and navigation systems available in the Lunar Module are many, and can be quite involved. In this lesson, we will start with some theory, before diving into the operations.
During this lesson you will need to switch between the CSM and the LM to perform various tasks. Start by entering the Lunar Module by pressing F4.

First of all, as we are in space, there is no way of telling what's up and down. The solution to this is to define a frame of reference, based on known directions, and use this as the reference platform.

This reference frame can change throughout the mission, and what it is defined as is not yet important. What's important is that this frame of reference is defined in the Lunar Guidance Computer, and in the Abort Guidance System.
The PNGS uses the LGC and an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) to keep track of this frame of reference.
The IMU is a device on-board the LM, that keeps track of any attitude and acceleration changes, and use this to update the orientation and state vector (position, velocity).
The IMU needs some time to start and become operational. Please estimate a few minutes before the IMU is ready. To start the process, close the IMU OPR circuit breaker on Panel 11.
The NO ATT light on the Lunar Guidance Computer is illuminated when the IMU isn't operational, and extinguished when the LGC is receiving information from it.

Your attitude relative to this platform can be visualized on the Commanders' and Lunar Module Pilots' FDAI. This is the big instrument on Panel 1 and Panel 2, with a ball that indicates your attitude.

This ball will show your angular attitude relative to the stable platform that the IMU is keeping track of. It can also show you angular rates using the YAW, PITCH and ROLL rate indicators, and attitude error using the yellow lines hovering on the ball.
The error indicators will try to point you to the attitude requested by the LGC.
Before we perform any attitude changes, we need to undock from the Command and Service Module. We will not go into the correct procedures for this here, but let's close the hatch before proceeding.

To close the hatch, turn around and press [C] to open the tools and communication menu. Use the flashlight, and look back into the room behind the crew stations. Along the roof, there should be a hatch, with a button next to it.
If the hatch is open, press the button to close it. Air inside the tunnel will be used to push the spacecrafts apart once the docking system releases the Lunar Module.
With the tunnel closed, go to the Command and Service Module by pressing F4.
On the CSM Panel 1, enable the Translation Controller power. We will need it to fire the thrusters to increase the separation velocity once we release the Lunar Module.
Next, release the Lunar Module by setting the Docking Probe to EXT/REL.
The CSM and LM is now separated. Reverse the CSM from the LM by adding some thrust, and pitch it a little bit to give the LM some room.
The Lunar Module and the CSM should now, very slowly, drift apart. If not, control the CSM so this happens. Press ROGER when ready.
Now press F4 to switch into the Lunar Module again.
First, let's pressurize the RCS system again.

To do this, follow the RCS PRESSURIZATION checklist, located in the ACTIVATION section in the LUNAR MODULE checklists tab. You can find it by scrolling down to almost the middle of the pad, just before the RCS HOT/COLD FIRING CHECK. Press SET UP RCS, and ROGER when complete.
With the RCS pressurized, we will move on to activate the RCS system next.
The TCA's also need power and should already be powered. Verify that the RCS SYS A, QUAD 1 TCA on panel 11 is closed.
Verify RCS SYS A, QUAD 2 TCA to closed.
Verify RCS SYS A, QUAD 3 TCA to closed.
Verify RCS SYS A, QUAD 4 TCA to closed.
Verify RCS SYS B, QUAD 1 TCA to closed.
Verify RCS SYS B, QUAD 2 TCA to closed.
Verify RCS SYS B, QUAD 3 TCA to closed.
Verify RCS SYS B, QUAD 4 TCA to closed.
Then let's allow the reactants to flow to the quads.
Set the SYSTEM A THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 1 on panel 2 to OPEN to open the valve.
Set the SYSTEM A THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 2 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
Set the SYSTEM A THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 3 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
Set the SYSTEM A THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 4 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
Set the SYSTEM B THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 1 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
Set the SYSTEM B THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 2 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
Set the SYSTEM B THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 3 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
Set the SYSTEM B THRUSTER PAIR QUAD 4 on panel 2 to OPEN as well.
And lastly, open the main shutoff valve by setting the MAIN SOV SYS A switch to OPEN.
And the MAIN SOV SYS B switch to OPEN as well.
The RCS is now ready. The HOT/COLD FIRING CHECK goes through the right procedures for this, but you will need to know a bit more to understand that checklist, so we are keeping it simple.
We are now ready to get into the flight modes part of this lesson. The first flight mode we will test is the PULSE mode. We briefly touched this in the RCS lesson as well.
Set the ROLL switch on the ATTITUDE CONTROL section of Panel 3 to PULSE.
Set PITCH to PULSE as well.
And finally, set YAW to PULSE.

Now, the spacecraft is in a flight mode where each stick deflection or keyboard input will produce a short pulse. The longer you keep the deflection, the longer the pulse will be. Each pulse has a maximum length of 200 ms.
The IMU should be up and running now, and the attitude of the spacecraft should be visible on the FDAI.
Try the pulse mode now, and try to get used to how it operates. Are you able to navigate the attitude so that the FDAI indicates an attitude where pitch and yaw is 0?
The rate indicators of the FDAI shows at what rate you are turning. Try to turn slowly, as conserving fuel is a major focus when flying the Lunar Module. Slow turns saves fuel.
Null all your rates, and press ROGER when ready.
Let's give more control to the Lunar Guidance Computer. Leave the ROLL switch in the ATTITUDE CONTROL section of Panel 3 to PULSE.
Then set PITCH to MODE CONT.
Set YAW to MODE CONT.
The LGC and DAP is now in control on PITCH and YAW. Set the PGNS switch in the MODE CONTROL section to ATT HOLD.
The spacecraft is now in ATTITUDE HOLD mode. We also need to instruct the computer on how to handle attitude change commands.
We do this by using the DSKY of the Lunar Guidance Computer.
Press VERB on the DSKY.
Press 7 on the DSKY.
Again, press 7 on the DSKY. Verify that the VERB display is set to 77.
Then press ENTR to insert it to the LGC.

This configures the ATTITUDE HOLD mode into a Rate Command and Attitude Hold mode. Each stick deflection produces a thrust. When the stick is released, the LGC will try to maintain the spacecraft at the attitude you had when releasing the stick.
In this mode, the longer you deflect the stick, the more acceleration it will produce.
Try to apply some pitch now. Start with some short bursts.
Notice that the spacecrafts tries to stop the rates when you release the deflection.
Try to pitch up, and keep the deflection (hold the pitch up key or axis in a deflection position).
Notice that the spacecraft accelerates up to a set limit, and then drifts slowly. When you release the stick, it will once again try to stop the rates.
The Digital Autopilot is used to configure the maximum turn rate.
When the stick is released, the DAP kicks in and tries to maintain that attitude. Pay close attention to the rates, and you will see that they are still moving.
The DAP won't be able to completely null the rates of the spacecraft. A spacecraft will always have a turn rate, just like a ship on the ocean can't go in a perfectly straight line.
The DAP is configured to allow a set dead band. Let's say this is set to 5 degrees. The spacecraft will try to maneuver to the attitude when you released the stick.

If the spacecraft goes outside of the dead band, meaning 5 degrees away from the target attitude, the LGC will command a select set of thrusters to try to maneuver the spacecraft back into the correct attitude.
The lower this dead band is, the more attitude changes will be performed by the LGC.
It's important to balance this. When there is no need for precise attitudes, keep the dead band high to save fuel.

Play around with this for a while, and get comfortable flying the Lunar Module in this mode. It will be one of your primary maneuvering modes. It's important to practice now that the spacecraft is set up, as it takes a while do get up here each time. Press ROGER when ready to proceed.
Let's jump back to the computer.
The computer can be used to monitor a lot of the input and output channels of the LGC. For example, channel 31 contains attitude change impulses, as well as the flight mode.
To monitor channel 31, press VERB on the DSKY.
Then key 1.
Then key 1 again. Verify that the VERB field contains 11. If not, you can press CLR to clear the current input field.
Then key NOUN on the DSKY.
Then key 1, it should appear in the NOUN field.
Then key 0. Verify that the NOUN field contains 10.
VERB 11 means Monitor Octal Component 1 in R1, and NOUN 10 means Channel to be specified.
Press ENTR to insert the command.
Now, the LGC expects the channel it should monitor. Key 3 on the DSKY.
Then key 1. The field in R3 should now contain 31.
Then press ENTR to start monitoring channel 31.
Based on the configuration of the spacecraft, the value in R1 should reflect the LGC flight mode and what thrusters it WISH to fire.
In this mode, when idling, it should read 67777.
This is a number in the Octal Numeral system. Converting 67777 to binary will result in a set of ON and OFF bits reflecting the configuration of the LGC.
67777 is equal to 110111111111111 in binary. Channel 31 uses inverted bits, so let's invert this as well. The inverted bit sequence is 001000000000000.
In addition, it is also reversed, so the reversed bit sequence is 000000000000100.
Bit 13 is set to 1. Now, looking up in the Reentry Lunar Module Flight Manual, in the PGNS chapter, bit 13 in channel 13 means ATTITUDE HOLD.
We are now in attitude hold mode, with no stick deflection. The LGC tries to hold an attitude.
If you pitch UP, it will read 27776, before changing to 27775, and returning back to 67777.
Doing the same for 27776 results in 100000000000101.
Bit 1 is the +Pitch command, bit 13 is still attitude hold, and bit 15 is that the stick is out of detent.

This can be good to use to check if things are in order, and is part of the HOT/COLD FIRING CHECK. In addition Channel 5 and 6 can be monitored to see each of the thrusters that the LGC wish to command.
Now that we are discussing the computer, let's also check the DAP setup.
The DAP is using an extended verb to run the setup.
On the DSKY, press ENTR to exit the monitoring of channel 31.
Then insert Verb 48 and press ENTR. This is usually shortened to V48E, meaning press VERB, then 4, then 8, then ENTR. Do this now.

When doing this, the DAP setup has started. The first page we are viewing is located in NOUN 46, and displays two octal numbers, one in register 1 (R1), and another in register 2 (R2). R2 is currently zero, most likely.
What we are interested in is R1.
Each of the digits in R1 represents a configuration, and can be read as ABCDE. Open the DAP setup checklist in the Lunar Module checklists part of the Mission Pad.
You can use V21E to change R1. Change R1 into +12122 and press ENTR to make the change.
Then press PRO to continue the setup.

This allows you to enter the weights of the LM and the CSM. Leave them in their default values for now, or request the weights using the circular button (toggle with C) and insert the values. Press PRO to complete the setup.
This allows you to reach faster attitude rates, but also costs more fuel to both accelerate into a turn rate, and decelerate out from the rate to maintain an attitude.
The R62 Crew Defined Manuever routine will let you maneuver the spacecraft towards an attitude. It works similar to what the CSM has.
With the DAP set up, we can use V49E to start the routine. Key V 4 9 E now.
The first screen will display the attitude you wish to set as the target. You can use V21, V22, V23 or V25 to modify these. Press PRO to accept the values.
Now it requests the auto-maneuver. Set the PGNS mode to AUTO and the ROLL, PITCH and YAW switches to MODE CONT.
Then press PRO to accept the request. The spacecraft should start to maneuver towards the desired attitude.
This concludes the flight modes lesson. I know there was a lot to it, and I recommend you to now read the GUIDANCE & CONTROL chapter of the Reentry Lunar Module Flight Manual.
Good job, feel free to continue practicing!

Title: Lesson 6 - Flight Modes
Description: In the previous lessons, you have learned all the systems needed to start maneuvering the Lunar Module. In this lesson, we will look at some of the flight modes available, and how to switch between them.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Instructor: Patrick
Level: Advanced

In this lesson, we will look at some of the flight modes available, and how to switch between them.
